quoteFirst: Within minutes of the assassination, Brennan described the man to the police.[C4-254] This description most probably led to the radio alert sent to police cars at approximately
quoteLast: , which described the suspect as white, slender, weighing about 165 pounds, about 5’10” tall, and in his early thirties.[C4-255] In his sworn statement to the police later that day, Brennan described the man in similar terms, except that he gave the weight as between 165 and 175 pounds and the height was omitted.
title: Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President John F. Kennedy
author: United States. Warren Commission

quoteFirst: At 7.25 a.m. steered north 110 degrees east, over grassy ironbark ridges, with small watercourses trending north; at 11.0 entered a dense brigalow scrub with a few Moreton-Bay ash-trees, the soil very poor and derived from the decomposition of a coarse conglomerate; small watercourses trending to the south. At
quoteLast: emerged from the scrub into open box forest, with limestone and quartz gravel, and a soft black soil producing rather dry scanty grass. At 1.45 entered a well-grassed plain with limestone ridges covered with bottle-tree scrub; the grass was good at this season, green but much mixed with salsola; the summits of Peak Range showed well above the ridges, and from the cliff around the tops seem to be capped with sandstone or more probably porphyry.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteLast: enemy sprung mine between craters 3 and 4, filling up our saps and connecting trench. The damage was repaired.
title: The History of the 7th Battalion Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders
author: Sandilands, James Walter; MacLeod, Norman, 1872-1960

quoteFirst: At the time of the assassination, Tippit was alone in his patrol car, the routine practice for most police patrol cars at this time of day. He had been ordered by radio at
quoteLast: to proceed to the central Oak Cliff area as part of a concentration of patrol car activity around the center of the city following the assassination. At 12:54 Tippit radioed that he had moved as directed and would be available for any emergency.
title: Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President John F. Kennedy
author: United States. Warren Commission

quoteLast: Our T.M. Battery fired 12 footballs, and our Stokes gun 32 shells at enemy’s front line trench in F10/5. The enemy sent a few canisters over, but then resorted to H.E.’s.
title:
Nothing of Importance

quoteFirst: "I arrived at Wilhelmshöhe on the morning of September 5th, and I was asked to 'report' to the Kaiser at
quoteLast: This expression was chosen because the new head of the Kaiser's Civil Cabinet, Herr v. Berg, evidently wished to invest my visit with an official character which would enable him to be in attendance.
title: Albert Ballin
author: Huldermann, Bernhard; Eggers, Wilhelm Johann [Translator]

quoteFirst: Leaves Chicago 9.00 a. m., arrives at Utica 11.25 a. m. (dinner), leaves Utica 12.10 p. m., arrives Trenton Falls
quoteLast: , Clayton, 4.05 p. m. Immediate connection with Steamboat for Round Island, Thousand Island Park, and Westminster Park, arrives Alexandria Bay 5.10 p. m.
title:
"Chicago to the Sea." Eastern Excursionist
A complete guide to the principal eastern summer resorts, including: Niagara Falls, the White Mountains, Saint Lawrence and Saguenay Rivers, Montreal and Quebec, the New England sea beaches, etc., and how and when to enjoy them.
author: Gage, William C.

quoteLast: ; length, 15 minutes.
title: Wonders of the Yellowstone
author: Richardson, James (Geologist)

quoteFirst: _Commission finding._--The radio logs of the Dallas Police Department and the Dallas County Sheriff’s Office show that no description of a suspect in the assassination of the President was broadcast before
quoteLast: on that day. No reference to Oswald by name was broadcast before he was arrested. The description of the suspect that was broadcast was similar to that of Oswald, but it lacked some important specific details such as color of hair and eyes.
title: Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President John F. Kennedy
author: United States. Warren Commission

quoteFirst: 0 passed a large sandy hill, covered with short scrub, and halted at 11.0 in a grassy gully in the bottom of a wide scrubby valley; at
quoteLast: again resumed our journey, and ascending the sandy downs, at 1.15 gained the highest ridge.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteFirst: An attempt to wire the edge of the wood was frustrated by a counter-attack, which men of the 10th Bavarian Division delivered against the north-east corner about 3 P.M. This attack was easily repulsed by rifle-fire, but the situation was critical, and between
quoteLast: and 1.15 P.M. reports from the 26th Brigade and the 52nd Brigade R.F.A. having stated that the Germans were massing on the north-west of the wood, the artillery put a protective barrage round it.
title: The history of the 9th (Scottish) Division, 1914-1919
author: Ewing, John, M.C.; Plumer of Messines, Herbert Charles Onslow Plumer, Viscount, 1857-1932 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Churchill, Winston, 1874-1965 [Illustrator]; Hodge, F. E. (Francis Edwin), 1883-1949 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Lightoller, the second officer, is to be believed, that both he and the master knew that the danger of meeting ice still existed. Mr. Lightoller says that the master showed him the _Caronia_ message about
quoteLast: on April 14, when he was on the bridge. He was about to go off watch, and he says he made a rough calculation in his head which satisfied him that the _Titanic_ would not reach the position mentioned in the message until he came on watch again at 6 p. m. At 6 p. m. Mr.
title: Loss of the Steamship "Titanic"
author: Great Britain. Court to investigate loss of steamship "Titanic"

quoteFirst: 30, when we entered a grassy flat timbered with casuarina; at 10.25 the country was more open, but scrubby; at
quoteLast: observed a small lake bearing 10 degrees; steered on that course, and reached it at 2.10 p.m.; halted till 3.15, and then resumed our former course through a swampy country, and at 4.50 camped on the bank of another small shallow lake.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888
